nodes.text: Loaders are devided into
2 main groups
- loaders themself and skeletons.
Inside this groups there are also different types of elements. On the sheme below you can find the division.
Loaders
Types
There are three visually distinct types of progress indicators:
spinner, waver, progress bar

. Only one type should represent each kind of activity in an app. For example, if a refresh action displays a spinner indicator on one screen, that same action shouldn’t use a waver indicator elsewhere.

When the process of loading is completed and for users it’s visually not viewable, that the process has changed something, like sending contact form it’s better to show notification, that the process was successful, after the loader has disappeared.
Determinate indicators
Indeterminate indicators
Determinate indicators show how long a process will take. They should be used when the process with a known duration.

Indeterminate indicators express an unknown amount of wait time. They should be used when website performs an unquantifiable task, such as loading or synchronizing complex data or if it’s not necessary to indicate how long an activity will take.
Use it when the process with well-defined duration.
Use it to communicate the status of a background operation or when space is constrained.
Always report progress accurately.
When possible, switch from an indeterminate progress bar to a determinate progress bar.
Hide in
di
cator after it’s completely filled.
Don’t transition from a spinner to a progress bar.
If it’s helpful, include a label to indicator to add context.
Keep indeterminate progress indicators moving so people know something is happening.
Spinner
Behavior
Spinner displays progress by animating an indicator along an invisible circular track in a clockwise direction. They can be applied directly to a surface, such as a button or card.
Integrating with actions

A spinner can be integrated into a button or actionable icon to express a connection between an interaction and a specific item. They are typically used to express when an interaction, such as clicking a button again, isn’t available.
They should be used for short, indeterminate activities
(between
2-5 seconds). Longer activities may require alternate methods of communication, such as snackbars or notifications.

In cases, when spinner was used to submit something or sent, for example after sending contact form, after spinner has worked, sending was completed and spinner disappeared, it’s good to show some notification that the process was successful.
Waver
Behavior
Waver displays progress by animating an indicator that the points gradually rise and fall. They are not as used as spinners, but can be used
for specific cases
, when the spinner doesn’t work well, for example while a person is typing in chat.
Integrating with actions
They should be used for short, indeterminate activities
(between
2-5 seconds). Longer activities may require alternate methods of communication, such as snackbars or notifications.
If for some element in some place, for example a card, if you  have already used a spinner, we can’t use waver in other places.
Progress bar
Behavior
Progress bar display progress by animating an indicator along the length of a fixed, visible track. The behavior of the indicator is dependent on whether the progress of a process is known.
When a lot of elements are loading together it’s better to use skeletons. Progress bars can be used for loading some specific element.
Types
Progress bar support both determinate and indeterminate operations.
Determinate operations display the indicator increasing in width from 0 to 100% of the track, in sync with the process’s progress.
Indeterminate operations display the indicator continually growing and shrinking along the track until the process is complete.
For better overview of how to use different types of indicator review section
“determined
and Indetermined”
Determined progress bar is also divided into simple, percent, stripped and indicator. Simple, percent and stripped progress bar could be used equally depending on what you think will look better.
Indicator CAN ONLY BE USED FOR SHOWING UPLOADING OF PAGE.
Size of elements
There are 3 possible size of loaders to use: large, medium, small.
The main rule of using appropriate size of element is that their size should be
visually proportional
to the element for which it is used.
So large elements should be basically used for some big elements, such as the whole page or big section.

Medium elements should be used for smaller sections or elements, like cards. But if you have already used a large loader size for a similar type of component, you should choose only one of them and use it everywhere in the system.
Small size elements should logically be used for small components, such as buttons. Use the size option when you need to increase or decrease the visual weight of the loader.
Sceletons
Types
There are four types of skeletons: item, text block, person, card. Skeleton page is used with other skeleton loading components to provide a low fidelity representation of the user interface
(UI)
before content appears on the page.
Behaviour
On launch, core structural elements – such as the status bar, app bar, and bottom sheet – are displayed without content until the app has loaded.
Placeholder elements, with subtle animation, should be displayed in locations where content will load.
Use also indicator while loading the page.
Placeholder elements should remain positioned where content will load to avoid unexpected shifts in positioning.
Best practices
Try to match the number of lines of the text block to the content being loaded so it gives an accurate representation.
Show static content that never changes on a page and
use skeleton loading for dynamic content
. Skeleton text block can sometimes be used to represent non-typographic content such as forms. Don’t use placeholder content that will change when the page fully loads.
